title: I Never Liked Mayo Until I Discovered a Jar of This (It's Always in My Fridge!)

I’ve been on a condiment kick for a while now. I realized it’s the easiest way to take a low-lift dinner to the next level, and I haven’t looked back since. I’ll make some scrambled eggs for breakfast, and as soon as I drizzle some chili crunch on top, it takes them from boring to out-of-this-world. I’ll whip up some plain ramen noodles, but mixing in some Korean barbecue sauce gives them a sweet and spicy kick that has me clearing my plate. I’ve even started putting punchy buffalo sauce on my frozen pizzas.

But mayo is one condiment that I just was never able to get behind. I’ve never put it on my sandwiches, despite eating them so often in my school lunches as a kid. It always came across as too bland, and the texture … I cringe just thinking about it. I never thought I would see the day that I would tolerate mayo, let alone actually enjoy it — but in the spirit of trying new things in the new year, I took a chance on one. To my surprise, Cabi’s Vegan Spicy Mayo has completely won me over.

What Is Cabi’s Vegan Spicy Mayo?

If Cabi hasn’t already gotten on your radar or found its way onto your grocery list yet, let me introduce you to the brand. First off, in Japanese, Cabi means “mold” — as in Koji mold, which is found in things like soy sauce and sake. The brand was founded in 2022 with the intention of “shar[ing] the beauty and ease of Japanese home cooking.” It started off with three products in its lineup: an umami dashi soy sauce, miso glaze, and a sweet yuzu vinaigrette (all of which I love, too). What’s more, for its ingredients, the brand collaborates with Japanese producers who have been making their products for generations.

According to Cabi, its Japanese Spicy Mayo is the first of its kind, and it launched last year after 18 months of development. Instead of consisting of egg and oil like standard mayos, this condiment is plant-based, crafted from sake less (a nutrient-packed filtered residue that comes from sake production). It’s designed to go on everything from sandwiches to sushi, giving it all a creamy kick.

Why I Love Cabi’s Vegan Spicy Mayo

I consider myself a regular mayo hater — Cabi’s take on the condiment is the exception. As you probably guessed, this was my first time trying a spicy mayo, too. I was instantly shocked at how pleasantly different this alternative is. It lacks the too-creamy, overwhelming texture that’s always turned me off from mayo. Instead, it’s smooth and light to complement a wider range of dishes; it would be nearly undetectable on a sandwich if it wasn’t so full of flavor and if it didn’t help by making the bread less dry. I haven’t made a sandwich without this mayo since I added it to my fridge, pairing perfectly with my turkey and cheese as well as grilled chicken ones.

The spice level is pleasant alongside the umami notes. For reference, I’ve been building up my spice tolerance over the past year, but I’m still not the biggest fan of anything that’s flaming hot. Cabi’s mayo is an excellent alternative when you want some kick, but you don’t want something as intense as hot sauce. I drizzled it over my broccoli and finished my serving in record time, never having to stop to gulp down water. The same can be said for my California roll.

A little goes a long way with this Vegan Spicy Mayo, so I don’t think I’ll need to replace my bottle anytime soon — the soft, squeezable bottle is another nice way it stands apart from jarred mayo. But as soon as I notice it running out, I’m going to rush to Amazon to order more. I’m keeping it stocked in my fridge until further notice!

Buy: Cabi Vegan Spicy Mayo (2-pack), $23.99
